title: Cat. 91  Fragment of a Vessel, 1st century B.C./mid-1st century A.D.
publication_title: Roman Art at the Art Institute of Chicago
content:
<section class="osci-tk-epub-section tombstone" id="tombstone">Fragment of a Vessel  
1st century B.C./mid-1st century A.D.  
Roman  
Glass, mosaic glass technique; 5 × 3.6 × 0.9 cm (2 × 1 7/16 × 3/8 in.)  
The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of Theodore W. and Frances S. Robinson, 1949.1229

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section curatorial_entry" id="curatorial_entry">Transparent deep-blue, amethyst, aquamarine, and opaque white and yellow glass. Bowl or dish fragment fabricated by the mosaic glass technique, tooled, and polished. The fragment preserves the wall of a large, deep bowl with heavy vertical ribs. The mosaic pattern is formed from sections of three polygonal canes; one in deep blue with ten white dots around a central yellow dot; two canes in amethyst with nine white dots around a central yellow dot; a third fragmentary cane appears to be an aquamarine matrix with white dots.

The fragment preserves the lower part of a large vertical rib on the exterior of a deep bowl. The interior is repolished with isolated pitting. There is a light-brown weathering crust and some silvery iridescence on the back and all edges.  
Sidney Goldstein

</section><section id="figures">Cat. 91 Fragment of a Vessel, 1st century B.C./mid-1st century A.D.

</section>
